generif.text: Two missense mutations (S206P, D468V), two splicing defects (IVS12-1G>C, IVS13-2delA), one nonsense mutation (Q436X), one insertion/deletion mutation (2104-2105delGGins29-bp), and an intragenic deletion of SLC26A3 gene.

Endogenous and recombinant human/mouse Slc26a3 do not exhibit electrogenic 2Cl-/1HCO- exchange. Acute induction of Slc26a3 Cl-/HCO3- exchange is associated with secondary membrane potential changes representing homeostatic responses.

MF.term: secondary active sulfate transmembrane transporter activity

name: solute carrier family 26 member 3

reactome.name: Transport of inorganic cations/anions and amino acids/oligopeptides
Defective SLC26A3 causes congenital secretory chloride diarrhea 1 (DIAR1)

summary: The protein encoded by this gene is a transmembrane glycoprotein that transports chloride ions across the cell membrane in exchange for bicarbonate ions. It is localized to the mucosa of the lower intestinal tract, particularly to the apical membrane of columnar epithelium and some goblet cells. The protein is essential for intestinal chloride absorption, and mutations in this gene have been associated with congenital chloride diarrhea. [provided by RefSeq, Oct 2008].
